newsitem.title: LATVIA: LATVIA-ECONOMY MINISTER BRUSHES OFF ALLEGATIONS.
newsitem.headline: LATVIA-ECONOMY MINISTER BRUSHES OFF ALLEGATIONS.

text.p: Latvian Economy Minister Guntar Krasts denied conflict of interest allegations on Friday and said he sees no reason for resigning.

Saimnieks, the biggest party in the country's unweildy eight-party coalition, submitted materials to Prime Minister Andris Shkele on May 22 which alleged that Krasts violated anti-corruption laws by keeping his post in an alcohol trading company after he became minister.
Krasts said that his ties with the company ceased in 1995.
"I do not think I have to resign," Krasts told a news conference.
Krasts, representing the coalition's third biggest party, Fatherland and Freedom (FP), said Saimnieks was trying to force FP out of the government.
"If similar attempts continues I see a possibility that FP might leave the coalition," Krasts said.
Shkele has demanded additional information on the issue from the relevant state bodies and will have a "clearer view of the situation" on Monday, a government spokesman told Reuters.

The Latvian government is going through a rough patch this month with the defence minister sacked amid a fuel purchace scandal and the welfare minister resigning over a pension law disagreement with DSP.
